MATH 1111.description: Study of the properties of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions as needed for pre-calculus and calculus.
MATH 1111.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18
MATH 1111.title: College Algebra

MATH 1113.description: Analytic geometry, the function concept, polynomials, exponential, logarithms, trigonometric functions, mathematical induction, the theory of equations.
MATH 1113.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1113.prereqs: Math 1111 with a minimum grade of D or Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 530 or ACT score of 21.
MATH 1113.title: Precalculus

MATH 1501.description: See MATH 1551 and new math core for Fall 2015. Differential calculus and basic integral calculus including the fundamental theorem of calculus, including the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences.
MATH 1501.prereqs: Math SAT score of 600 or higher, or MATH 1113 Precalculus.
MATH 1501.title: Calculus I

MATH 1502.description: See MATH 1552, 1553, 1554, 1564. Concludes the treatment of single variable calculus, and begins linear algebra; the linear basis of the multivariable theory. The first 1/3 of this course covers more advanced single variable calculus. The remaining 2/3 is an introduction to linear algebra, the theory of linear equations in several variables.
MATH 1502.title: Calculus II

MATH 1503.description: Single variable differential and integral calculus: sequences and difference equations, limit and continuity, differentiation and integration and applications. The topics covered parallel those of MATH 1501 but the applications and examples are drawn from life sciences instead of physical sciences.
MATH 1503.prereqs: Math SAT score 600 or higher, or converted ACT Math 600 or higher, or MATH 1113 Precalculus minimum grade of D.
MATH 1503.title: Calculus I for Life Sciences

MATH 1504.description: Taylor approximations, introduction to differential equations, linear algebra and introduction to multivariable calculus. Motivating examples drawn from life sciences.
MATH 1504.prereqs: MATH 1503 or MATH 1501 or MATH 1511 or MATH 15X1.
MATH 1504.title: Calculus II for Life Sciences

MATH 1512.description: This course is designed for students who have had a serious single variable calculus course in high school.
MATH 1512.extra: Non-HP Section - AP Calculus BC score of 5, must apply in July
MATH 1512.prereqs: HP Section - for Honors Program students only
MATH 1512.title: Honors Calculus II

MATH 1522.description: Will be replaced by MATH 1553. See also MATH 1554, 1564. Transfer students with credit for MATH 15X2 (Transfer Calculus II) should take MATH 1522 to satisfy the linear algebra requirement in MATH 1502.
MATH 1522.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra for Calculus

MATH 1550.description: An introduction to differential calculus including the theory of limits for functions and sequences (only for Summer Freshmen).
MATH 1550.prereqs: SAT Math score of 600 or Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 620 or ACT 26 or ACT equivalent 600 or MATH 1113 Precalculus.
MATH 1550.title: Introduction to Differential Calculus

MATH 1551.description: Differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences.
MATH 1551.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1551.prereqs: Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 620 or ACT 26 or ACT equivalent 600 or MATH 1113 Precalculus.
MATH 1551.title: Differential Calculus

MATH 1552.description: Definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, improper integrals, infinite series, applications.
MATH 1552.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1552.prereqs: MATH 1550 or MATH 1551 or MATH 1501 or MATH 15X1 or MATH 1X51.
MATH 1552.title: Integral Calculus

MATH 1553.description: An introduction to linear algebra through eigenvalues and eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares.
MATH 1553.extra: MATH 1553, MATH 1554, and MATH 1564 are equivalent and only one can be taken for credit. Note: MATH 4305 cannot be used for credit in the BS MTH degree.
MATH 1553.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1553.prereqs: Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 620 or ACT 26 or ACT equivalent 600 or MATH 1113 Precalculus or 15X2 or 1X52 or MATH 1552 Integral Calculus.
MATH 1553.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra

MATH 1554.description: Linear algebra through eigenvalues, eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares, diagonalization, quadratic forms.
MATH 1554.extra:
MATH 1553, MATH 1554, and MATH 1564 are equivalent and only one can be taken for credit.
Note: MATH 4305 cannot be used for credit in the BS MTH degree.
MATH 1554.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1554.prereqs: Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 620 or ACT 26 or ACT equivalent 600 or MATH 1113 Precalculus or 15X2 or 1X52 or MATH 1552 Integral Calculus.
MATH 1554.title: Linear Algebra

MATH 1555.description: Overview of integral calculus, multivariable calculus, and differential equations for biological sciences. This course is required for students in School of Biology.
MATH 1555.prereqs: MATH 1550 or MATH 1551 or MATH 1501 or MATH 15X1 or MATH 1X51
MATH 1555.title: Calculus for Life Sciences

MATH 1564.description: This is an intensive course on linear algebra, taught at a sophisticated and abstract level.
MATH 1564.extra:
MATH 1553, MATH 1554, and MATH 1564 are equivalent and only one can be taken for credit.
Note: MATH 4305 cannot be used for credit in the BS MTH degree.
MATH 1564.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1564.prereqs: Score of 5 in AP BC Calculus or A in MATH 1552 or equivalent or permission from Academic Office.
MATH 1564.title: Linear Algebra with Abstract Vector Spaces

MATH 1711.description: Linear equations, matrices, linear programming, sets and counting, probability and statistics.
MATH 1711.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1711.prereqs: Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 570 or ACT 24 or ACT equivalent 550, or MATH 1113 Precalculus.
MATH 1711.title: Finite Mathematics

MATH 1712.description: Functions, the derivative, applications of the derivative, techniques of differentiation, integration, applications of integration to probability and statistics, multidimensional calculus.
MATH 1712.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 1712.prereqs: Math SAT Section Score (new SAT) of 570 or ACT 24 or ACT equivalent 550, or MATH 1113 Precalculus.
MATH 1712.title: Survey of Calculus

MATH 2106.description: An introduction to proofs in advanced mathematics, intended as a transition to upper division courses including MATH 4107, 4150 and 4317. Fundamentals of mathematical abstraction including sets, logic, equivalence relations, and functions. Thorough development of the basic proof techniques: direct, contrapositive, existence, contradiction, and induction. Introduction to proofs in analysis and algebra.
MATH 2106.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 2106.prereqs: ((MATH 1552 or MATH 15X2 or MATH 1X52) and (MATH 1553 or MATH 1554 or MATH 1564 or MATH 1522 or MATH 1X53))
MATH 2106.title: Foundations of Mathematical Proof

MATH 2401.description: Being replaced by MATH 2551. Multivariable calculus: Linear approximation and Taylor's theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss and Stokes.
MATH 2401.title: Calculus III

MATH 2403.description: Course being replaced by MATH 2552. Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling.
MATH 2403.title: Differential Equations

MATH 2406.description: A thorough development of the theory of linear algebra and an introduction to multilinear algebra, with selected applications.
MATH 2406.title: Abstract Vector Spaces

MATH 2411.description: The topics covered parallel those of 2401 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit is not allowed for both an honors calculus course and the corresponding regular calculus course.
MATH 2411.prereqs: You must have a B or higher in MATH 1502 or MATH 1512 to be enrolled in this course. If you are in MATH 1502 or MATH 1512 in the fall term, you may register for this course during Phase I of registration. In December, we will drop any students in 2411 who make C, D or F in 1502 or 1512.
MATH 2411.title: Honors Calculus III

MATH 2413.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling.
MATH 2413.prereqs: You must have a B or higher in MATH 2401, MATH 2411, or MATH 2605 to take this course.
MATH 2413.title: Honors Differential Equations

MATH 2550.description: An introduction to multivariable calculus through vectors in 3D, curves, functions of several variables, partial derivatives, min/max problems, multiple integration. Vector Calculus not covered.
MATH 2550.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 2550.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 2550.title: Introduction to Multivariable Calculus

MATH 2551.description: Linear approximation and Taylor’s theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes.
MATH 2551.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 2551.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 2551.title: Multivariable Calculus

MATH 2552.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling.
MATH 2552.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 2552.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 2552.title: Differential Equations

MATH 2561.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2551 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.
MATH 2561.extra:
MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53)).
If you are currently taking the perequisite course in the fall, you may register for this course during Phase I of registration. In December, we will drop any students in MATH 2561 who make C, D or F in the prerequisite course.
MATH 2561.prereqs: Grade at least B in the following:
MATH 2561.title: Honors Multivariable Calculus

MATH 2562.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2552 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.
MATH 2562.extra: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 2562.prereqs: Grade at least B in the following:
MATH 2562.title: Honors Differential Equations

MATH 2602.description: The course is being replaced in Fall 2015 by the equivalent course MATH 2603, Intro to Discrete Math. Mathematical logic and proof, mathematical induction, counting methods, recurrence relations, algorithms and complexity, graph theory and graph algorithms.
MATH 2602.title: Linear and Discrete Mathematics

MATH 2603.description: Mathematical logic and proof, mathematical induction, counting methods, recurrence relations, algorithms and complexity, graph theory and graph algorithms.
MATH 2603.extra: This course is equivalent to MATH 2602.
MATH 2603.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 2603.prereqs: MATH 1552 or MATH 1502 or MATH 1512 or MATH 15X2.
MATH 2603.title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics

MATH 2605.description: Topics in linear algebra and multivariate calculus and their applications in optimization and numerical methods, including curve fitting, interpolation, and numerical differentiation and integration.
MATH 2605.title: Calculus III for Computer Science

MATH 2802 LEY.description: Special Topics course offered in Spring 2017 by Anton Leykin. Restricted to CS students with credit for MATH 1553, MATH 1502 or MATH 1522.
MATH 2802 LEY.title: Applications of Linear Algebra

MATH 2802-ALG.description: Special Topics course offered in Spring 2017 by TBA. Restricted to CS students with credit for MATH 1553, MATH 1502 or MATH 1522.
MATH 2802-ALG.title: Applications of Linear Algebra

MATH 3012.description: Elementary combinatorial techniques used in discrete problem solving: counting methods, solving linear recurrences, graph and network models, related algorithms, and combinatorial designs.
MATH 3012.extra: CS students should complete CS 2050 before taking MATH 3012.
MATH 3012.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 3012.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 3012.title: Applied Combinatorics

MATH 3215.description: This course is a problem oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study.
MATH 3215.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 3215.prereqs: MATH 2401 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2561 or MATH 2550 or MATH 2X51 or MATH 2605.
MATH 3215.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics

MATH 3225.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 3215, with a more rigorous and intensive treatment. Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3215 and 3225.
MATH 3225.prereqs: You must have B or higher in MATH 2401, MATH 2411, or MATH 2605 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2561 to be enrolled in this course.  If you are in one of the above courses in the spring or summer term, you may register for MATH 3225 during Phase I of registration. In early August, we will drop any students in 3225 (fall term) who make C, D, or F in 2401, 2411, 2605, 2551 or 2561 in the spring or summer term.
MATH 3225.title: Honors Probability and Statistics

MATH 3235.description: This course is a mathematical introduction to probability theory, covering random variables, moments, multivariate distributions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, and large deviations.
MATH 3235.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 3235.prereqs: (MATH 2551 or MATH 2X51 or MATH 2561 or MATH 2401 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2605 or MATH 2550) AND (MATH 2106 or CS 2051 or MATH 3012)
MATH 3235.title: Probability Theory

MATH 3236.description: This course is an introduction to theoretical statistics for students with a background in probability. A mathematical formalism for inference on experimental data will be developed.
MATH 3236.title: Statistical Theory

MATH 3406.description: This course will cover important topics in linear algebra not usually discussed in a first-semester course, featuring a mixture of theory and applications.
MATH 3406.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 3406.prereqs: MATH 1553 or MATH 1554 or MATH 1564 or MATH 1502 or MATH 1512 or MATH 1522 or MATH 1X53
MATH 3406.title: A Second Course on Linear Algebra

MATH 3670.description: Introduction to probability, probability distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, linear regression and analysis of variance.
MATH 3670.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 3670.prereqs: MATH 2401 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2550 or MATH 2X51
MATH 3670.title: Probability and Statistics with Applications

MATH 3770.description: Introduction to probability, probability distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, linear regression and analysis of variance.
MATH 3770.schedule: Not offered any more. Replaced by MATH 3670.
MATH 3770.title: Statistics and Applications

MATH 4012.description: Introduction to linear error correcting codes with an emphasis on the algebraic tools required, including matrices, vector spaces, groups, polynomial rings, and finite fields.
MATH 4012.title: Algebraic Structures in Coding Theory

MATH 4022.description: The fundamentals of graph theory: trees, connectivity, Euler torus, Hamilton cycles, matchings, colorings and Ramsey theory.
MATH 4022.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 4022.title: Introduction to Graph Theory

MATH 4032.description: Combinatorial problem-solving techniques including the use of generating functions, recurrence relations, Polya theory, combinatorial designs, Ramsey theory, matroids, and asymptotic analysis.
MATH 4032.title: Combinatorial Analysis

MATH 4080.description: The first of a two course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.
MATH 4080.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4080.title: Senior Project I

MATH 4090.description: The second of a two course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.
MATH 4090.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4090.title: Senior Project II

MATH 4107.description: This course develops in the theme of "Arithmetic congruence, and abstract algebraic structures." There will be a very strong emphasis on theory and proofs.
MATH 4107.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4107.title: Abstract Algebra I

MATH 4108.description: Continuation of Abstract Algebra I, with emphasis on Galois theory, modules, polynomial fields, and the theory of linear associative algebra.
MATH 4108.title: Abstract Algebra II

MATH 4150.description: Primes and unique factorization, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, Diophantine equations, Diophantine approximations, quadratic reciprocity. Applications such as fast multiplication, factorization and encryption.
MATH 4150.prereqs: MATH 2406 or MATH 2106 or CS 3510 or CS 3511
MATH 4150.title: Introduction to Number Theory

MATH 4221.description: Simple random walk and the theory of discrete time Markov chains
MATH 4221.prereqs: MATH 3215 or MATH 3225 or MATH 3235 or MATH 3670 or MATH 3770 or ISYE 3770 or CEE 3770
MATH 4221.title: Stochastic Processes I

MATH 4222.description: Renewal theory, Poisson processes and continuous time Markov processes, including an introduction to Brownian motion and martingales
MATH 4222.title: Stochastic Processes II

MATH 4255.description: Topics include uniform random number generation, sampling from non-uniform distributions, and applications to stochastic simulation, simulated annealing and genetic algorithms. A review of basic probability and Markov chains makes the course largely self-contained.
MATH 4255.prereqs: MATH 3215 or MATH 3225 or MATH 3235 or MATH 3770 or ISYE 3770 or CEE 3770
MATH 4255.title: Monte Carlo Methods

MATH 4261.description: Sampling distributions, Normal, t, chi-square and F distributions. Moment generating function methods, Bayesian estimation and introduction to hypothesis testing
MATH 4261.prereqs: MATH 3215 or MATH 3225 or MATH 3235 or MATH 3670 or MATH 3770 or ISyE 3770 or CEE 3700
MATH 4261.title: Mathematical Statistics I

MATH 4262.description: Hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio tests, nonparametric tests, bivariate and multivariate normal distributions
MATH 4262.title: Mathematical Statistics II

MATH 4280.description: The measurement and quantification of information. These ideas are applied to the probabilistic analysis of the transmission of information over a channel along which random distortion of the message occurs.
MATH 4280.prereqs: MATH 3215 or MATH 3225 or MATH 3235 or MATH 3670 or MATH 3770 or ISyE 3770 or CEE 3700
MATH 4280.title: Introduction to Information Theory

MATH 4305.description: Linear algebra in R^n, standard Euclidean inner product in R^n, general linear spaces, general inner product spaces, least squares, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, symmetric matrices.
MATH 4305.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4305.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 4305.title: Topics in Linear Algebra

MATH 4317.description: Real numbers, topology of Euclidean spaces, Cauchy sequences, completeness, continuity and compactness, uniform continuity, series of functions, Fourier series
MATH 4317.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4317.title: Analysis I

MATH 4318.description: Differentiation of functions of one real variable, Riemann-Stieltjes integral, the derivative in R^n and integration in R^n
MATH 4318.offered: sp21, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4318.title: Analysis II

MATH 4320.description: Topics from complex function theory, including contour integration and conformal mapping
MATH 4320.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4320.prereqs: MATH 2401 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2550 or MATH 2X51
MATH 4320.title: Complex Analysis

MATH 4347.description: Method of characteristics for first and second order partial differential equations, conservation laws and shocks, classification of second order systems and applications.
MATH 4347.prereqs: (MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 24X3 or MATH 2552 or MATH 2562 or MATH 2X52) and (MATH 1522 or MATH 1553 or MATH 1554 or MATH 1564 or MATH 1502 or MATH 1512)
MATH 4347.title: Partial Differential Equations I

MATH 4348.description: Green's functions and fundamental solutions. Potential, diffusion and wave equations.
MATH 4348.title: Partial Differential Equations II

MATH 4431.description: Point set topology, topological spaces and metric spaces, continuity and compactness, homotopy and covering spaces
MATH 4431.title: Introduction to Topology

MATH 4432.description: Introduction to algebraic methods in topology. Includes homotopy, the fundamental group, covering spaces, simplicial complexes. Applications to fixed point theory and group theory.
MATH 4432.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology

MATH 4441.description: The theory of curves, surfaces, and more generally, manifolds. Curvature, parallel transport, covariant differentiation, Gauss-Bonet theorem
MATH 4441.prereqs: MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2561 or MATH 2X51
MATH 4441.title: Differential Geometry

MATH 4541.description: A broad introduction to the local and global behavior of nonlinear dynamical systems arising from maps and ordinary differential equations.
MATH 4541.prereqs: (MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 24X3 or MATH 2552 or MATH 2562 or MATH 2X52) and (MATH 1522 or MATH 1553 or MATH 1554 or MATH 1564 or MATH 1502 or MATH 1512)
MATH 4541.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations I

MATH 4542.description: A continuation of Dynamics and Bifurcations I
MATH 4542.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations II

MATH 4580.description: A study of the linear programming problem, including the simplex method, duality, and sensitivity analysis with applications to matrix games, integer programming and networks.
MATH 4580.title: Linear Programming

MATH 4581.description: Fourier series, Fourier integrals, boundary value problems for partial differential equations, eigenvalue problems
MATH 4581.offered: fa21, su21, sp21, fa20, su20, sp20, fa19, su19, sp19, fa18, su18, sp18, fa17
MATH 4581.prereqs: MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 24X3 or MATH 2552 or MATH 2562 or or MATH 2X52
MATH 4581.title: Classical Mathematical Methods in Engineering

MATH 4640.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms for some basic problems in computational mathematics. Discussion of both implementation issues and error analysis. Crosslisted with CX 4640 (formerly CS 4642).
MATH 4640.prereqs: MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 24X3 or MATH 2552 or MATH 2562 or MATH 2X52 or MATH 2603
MATH 4640.title: Numerical Analysis I

MATH 4641.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of initial and boundary value problems in differential equations.
MATH 4641.title: Numerical Analysis II

MATH 4755.description: Problems from the life sciences and the mathematical methods for solving them are presented. The underlying biological and mathematical principles and the interrelationships are emphasized.
MATH 4755.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 4755.title: Mathematical Biology

MATH 4777.description: Scientific computational algorithms on vector and parallel computers. Speedup, algorithm complexity, interprocesses communication, synchronization, modern algorithms for linear systems, programming techniques, code optimization.
MATH 4777.prereqs: MATH 1502 OR MATH 1512 OR MATH 1555 OR MATH 1504 ((MATH 1552 OR MATH 15X2 OR MATH 1X52) AND (MATH 1522 OR MATH 1553 OR MATH 1554 OR MATH 1564 OR MATH 1X53))
MATH 4777.title: Vector/Parallel Scientific Computing

MATH 4782.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum information theory, formalism of quantum mechanics, quantum gates, algorithms, measurements, coding, and information. Physical realizations and experiments. Crosslisted with PHYS 4782
MATH 4782.prereqs: MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 24X1 or MATH 2551 or MATH 2561 or MATH 2X51.
MATH 4782.title: Quantum Information and Quantum Computing

MATH 4801 UG.description:
Pass/fail basis.
This course provides students with a broad exposure to areas of mathematics research through weekly speakers.
MATH 4801 UG.prereqs: MATH 2551, MATH 2550, MATH 2552, MATH 2401, or MATH 2411
MATH 4801 UG.title: Undergraduate Seminar

MATH 4802.description: Pass/Fail basis. This course is intended to teach general mathematical problem solving skills, and to prepare students to take the Putnam Examination.
MATH 4802.title: Mathematical Problem Solving

MATH 4803 HP.description: Special Topics course for the Honors Program offered in Spring 2017 by Matt Baker. Joint with MATH 2803 QHS, for Video High School students.
MATH 4803 HP.prereqs: MATH 1502 or MATH 1512 or MATH 1504 or MATH 1555 or ((MATH 1552 or MATH 15X2 or MATH 1X52) and (MATH 1553 or MATH 1554 or MATH 1564 or MATH 1522 or MATH 1X53))
MATH 4803 HP.title: Number Theory and Cryptography

MATH 4803 HP-LEY.description: Special Topics course "Bridge to Mathematics" by Anton Leykin, for the Honors Program section and a general section, offered in Fall 2020.
MATH 4803 HP-LEY.title: Bridge to Mathematics

MATH 4803 LEY - Sp16.description: Special Topics course on Algebraic Computation and its Applications offered by Anton Leykin in Spring 2016.
MATH 4803 LEY - Sp16.title: Algebraic Computation and its Applications

MATH 4803-HOM.description: Special topics course offered in Spring 2020 by Jennifer Hom.
MATH 4803-HOM.prereqs: Math 1564 (Linear Algebra with Abstract Vector Spaces) or Math 2106 (Foundations of Mathematical Proof).
MATH 4803-HOM.title: Knot Theory and Grid Homology

MATH 4803-HP-LEY.description: Special topics course offered in Fall 2020 by Anton Leykin for the Honors Program (HP) crosslisted with a general section (LEY), on "Bridge to Mathematics"
MATH 4803-HP-LEY.prereqs: Informal prerequisite: some knowledge of discrete mathematics
MATH 4803-HP-LEY.title: Bridge to Mathematics

MATH 4803-LEV.description: Special topics course offered in Fall 2018 by Caitlin Leverson on "Introduction to Knot Theory"
MATH 4803-LEV.prereqs: MATH 1553, MATH 1554, MATH 1564 or permission from the instructor.
MATH 4803-LEV.title: Introduction to Knot Theory

MATH 4803-LIA.description: The lectures will focus on an introduction of modern data science techniques and the foundational mathematical concepts in linear algebra, probability, and basic optimization related with these techniques. Sufficient case studies with real-world data sets will be provided to illustrate how to use the learned techniques and how to choose an appropriate model. To gain hands-on experience of analyzing real-world datasets, students will be given programming exercises to practice and improve their programming skills while applying the newly acquired knowledge to those exercises. Homework assignments (assigned during the first 9 weeks) will test students' ability to generalize the techniques covered in each lecture to different examples. Projects will be assigned in Week 10 and students will work in groups of 3-4. The projects will have weekly milestones in weeks 11-14 culminating in a final presentation and report due at the end of the class.
MATH 4803-LIA.prereqs: Calculus I and II: Math 1551 and Math 1552; and Linear algebra, such as 1553 or 1554 or 1564.
MATH 4803-LIA.title: Science Based Data Science

MATH 4803-MAR.description: Special topics course on Geometric Group Theory, offered in Spring 2021 by Dan Margalit.
MATH 4803-MAR.prereqs: MATH 4107 and MATH 2106  or permission of instructor
MATH 4803-MAR.title: Geometric Group Theory

MATH 4803-MCC.description: Special topics course on Mathematical Capillarity, offered in Spring 2021 by John McCuan.
MATH 4803-MCC.prereqs: No formal prerequisites are required beyond calculus and ODE’s
MATH 4803-MCC.title: Mathematical Capillarity

MATH 4803-WAN.description: Topics class offered in FALL 2021 by Zhiyu Wang.
MATH 4803-WAN.prereqs: Linear algebra and some familiarity with graph theory
MATH 4803-WAN.title: Spectral Graph Theory

MATH 4873.description:
This is a 2 week intense course, with lectures in the morning and computational lab in the afternoon.
Students will be asked to have a laptop with Matlab on it.

The course will meet in the mornings for lecture, break for  lunch, and reconvene for the lab in the afternoons.
MATH 4873.title: Computations in Dynamics

MATH 6001.description: This course includes topics on professional development and responsible conduct of research. The course satisfies the GT RCR Academic Policy for Doctoral Students to complete in-person RCR training.
MATH 6001.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6001.title: Introduction to Graduate Mathematics

MATH 6014.description: Fundamentals, connectivity, matchings, colorings, extremal problems, Ramsey theory, planar graphs, perfect graphs. Applications to operations research and the design of efficient algorithms.
MATH 6014.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6014.title: Graph Theory

MATH 6112.description: An advanced course in Linear Algebra and applications.
MATH 6112.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6112.prereqs: Undergraduate linear algebra at the level of MATH 4305, and ability to write rigorous proofs at the level of MATH 2106.
MATH 6112.title: Advanced Linear Algebra

MATH 6121.description: Graduate level linear and abstract algebra including groups, rings, modules, and fields. (1st of two courses)
MATH 6121.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6121.prereqs: MATH 4107 and one of MATH 2406, MATH 4305, or permission of instructor
MATH 6121.title: Algebra I

MATH 6122.description: Graduate level linear and abstract algebra including rings, fields, modules, some algebraic number theory and Galois theory. (2nd of two courses)
MATH 6122.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6122.title: Algebra II

MATH 6221.description: Classical introduction to probability theory including expectation, notions of convergence, laws of large numbers, independence, large deviations, conditional expectation, martingales and Markov chains.
MATH 6221.title: Advanced Classical Probability Theory

MATH 6235.description: This is the second of a two-semester sequence that develops basic probability concepts and models for working with financial markets and derivative securities. Continuous-time parameter stochastic processes are emphasized in this course. Mathematical concepts are introduced as needed.
MATH 6235.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance II

MATH 6241.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes. Topics of this course include measure and integration foundations of probability, distribution functions, convergence concepts, laws of large numbers and central limit theory. (1st of two courses)
MATH 6241.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6241.title: Probability I

MATH 6242.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes. (2nd of two courses)
MATH 6242.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6242.title: Probability II

MATH 6262.description: Basic theories of statistical estimation, including optimal estimation in finite samples and asymptotically optimal estimation. A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of estimation utilized by statisticians.
MATH 6262.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6262.prereqs: MATH 4261, MATH 4262 or equivalent and MATH 6241
MATH 6262.title: Statistical Estimation

MATH 6263.description: Basic theories of testing statistical hypotheses, including a thorough treatment of testing in exponential class families. A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of hypothesis testing utilized by statisticians.
MATH 6263.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6263.prereqs: MATH 4261, MATH 4262 or equivalent, MATH 6241 and MATH 6262
MATH 6263.title: Testing Statistical Hypotheses

MATH 6266.description: Basic unifying theory underlying techniques of regression, analysis of variance and covariance, from a geometric point of view. Modern computational capabilities are exploited fully. Students apply the theory to real data through canned and coded programs.
MATH 6266.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6266.prereqs: MATH 4261, MATH 4262 or equivalent and MATH 6241
MATH 6266.title: Linear Statistical Models

MATH 6267.description: Multivariate normal distribution theory, correlation and dependence analysis, regression and prediction, dimension-reduction methods, sampling distributions and related inference problems, selected applications in classification theory, multivariate process control, and pattern recognition.
MATH 6267.prereqs: MATH 4261, MATH 4262 or equivalent and MATH 6241
MATH 6267.title: Multivariate Statistical Analysis

MATH 6300.description: Hausdorff dimension, box counting dimension, iterated function systems, continued fractions, number theory, Julia sets.
MATH 6300.title: Fractal Geometry

MATH 6307.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of ordinary differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, normal forms. (1st of two courses)
MATH 6307.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6307.prereqs: MATH 4541 and MATH 4542 or permission of the instructor
MATH 6307.title: Ordinary Differential Equations I

MATH 6308.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, and normal forms. (2nd of two courses)
MATH 6308.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6308.title: Ordinary Differential Equations II

MATH 6321.description: Complex integration, including Goursat's theorem; classification of singularities, the argument principle, the maximum principle; Riemann Mapping theorem; analytic continuation and Riemann surfaces; range of an analytic function, including Picard's theorem.
MATH 6321.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6321.title: Complex Analysis

MATH 6337.offered: fa21, sp21, fa20, sp20, fa19, sp19, fa18, sp18, fa17, sp17, fa16, sp16
MATH 6337.prereqs: MATH 4318 or consent of the School
MATH 6337.title: Real Analysis I

MATH 6338.description: Topics include L^p, Banach and Hilbert spaces, basic functional analysis.
MATH 6338.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, su18, sp18, su17, sp17, su16, sp16
MATH 6338.prereqs: MATH 4318 or consent of the school
MATH 6338.schedule: Every spring and some summer semesters
MATH 6338.title: Real Analysis II

MATH 6341.description: Introduction to the mathematical theory of partial differential equations covering the basic linear models of science and exact solution techniques.
MATH 6341.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6341.title: Partial Differential Equations I

MATH 6342.description: This course covers the general mathematical theory of linear stationary and evolution problems plus selected topics chosen on the instructor's interests.
MATH 6342.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6342.title: Partial Differential Equations II

MATH 6421.description: The study of zero sets of polynomials: algebraic varieties, regular and rational map, and the Zariski topology.
MATH 6421.title: Algebraic Geometry I

MATH 6441.description: The fundamental group, covering spaces, core topics in homology and cohomology theory including CW complexes, universal coefficients, and Poincare duality.
MATH 6441.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6441.prereqs: MATH 4107, MATH 4317 or MATH 4431, or consent of instructor
MATH 6441.title: Algebraic Topology I

MATH 6442.prereqs: MATH 6441 or equivalent or consent of instructor
MATH 6442.title: Algebraic Topology II

MATH 6451.description: Introduction to topological and metric spaces. Continuity, compactness, convergence, completion. Product and quotient spaces. Elementary homotopy.
MATH 6451.title: General Topology

MATH 6452.description: The differential topology of smooth manifolds.
MATH 6452.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6452.title: Differential Topology

MATH 6453.description: Continuation of MATH 6452, complementary to MATH 6441, MATH 6442, MATH 6455, MATH 6456, MATH 6421, MATH 6422.
MATH 6453.title: Geometric Topology

MATH 6455.description: Core topics in differential and Riemannian geometry including Lie groups, curvature, relations with topology.
MATH 6455.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6455.prereqs: MATH 4441 or MATH 6452 or permission of the instructor.
MATH 6455.title: Differential Geometry I

MATH 6514.description: Applied mathematics techniques to solve real-world problems. Topics include mathematical modeling, asymptotic analysis, differential equations and scientific computation. Prepares the student for MATH 6515. (1st of two courses)
MATH 6514.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6514.title: Industrial Mathematics I

MATH 6515.description: Applications of mathematical techniques from MATH 6514 to solve real-world problems. Group projects to solve industrial problems in topics chosen by the instructor. (2nd of two courses)
MATH 6515.title: Industrial Mathematics II

MATH 6580.description: Geometry, convergence, and structure of linear operators in infinite dimensional spaces. Applications to science and engineering, including integral equations and ordinary and partial differential equations.
MATH 6580.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, su18, fa17, su17, fa16, su16
MATH 6580.prereqs: MATH 2403 and one of MATH 2406, MATH 4305
MATH 6580.schedule: Every fall semester and some summers
MATH 6580.title: Introduction to Hilbert Spaces

MATH 6583.description: Volterra and Fredholm linear integral equations, relation to differential equations, solution methods, Fourier, Laplace and Mellin transforms, applications to boundary value problems and integral equations.
MATH 6583.prereqs: MATH 6701 or MATH 2403 and one of MATH 2406 or MATH 4305
MATH 6583.title: Integral Equations and Transforms

MATH 6635.description: This course contains the basic numerical and simulation techniques for the pricing of derivative securities.
MATH 6635.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6635.prereqs: MATH 2403 and MATH 3215 (or the equivalent), knowledge of computer programming, and MS QCF standing or some previous exposure to the topics of stocks, bonds and options.
MATH 6635.title: Numerical Methods in Finance

MATH 6640.description: Introduction to the implementation and analysis of numerical algorithms for the numerical solution of the classic partial differential equations of science and engineering.
MATH 6640.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6640.title: Introduction to Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations

MATH 6641.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for nonlinear partial differential equations including elliptic, hyperbolic, and/or parabolic problems.
MATH 6641.title: Advanced Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations

MATH 6643.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of the classic problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, SVD, eigenvalue problems. Crosslisted with CSE 6643.
MATH 6643.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6643.prereqs: MATH 2406 or MATH 4305 or consent of School
MATH 6643.title: Numerical Linear Algebra

MATH 6644.description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, fixed point methods, Newton quasi-Newton, updating, gradient methods. Crosslisted with CSE 6644.
MATH 6644.offered: fa21, sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6644.prereqs: MATH 2406 or MATH 4305 or consent of School
MATH 6644.title: Iterative Methods for Systems of Equations

MATH 6645.description: Theoretical and computational aspects of polynomial, rational, trigonometric, spline and wavelet approximation.
MATH 6645.title: Numerical Approximation Theory

MATH 6646.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for initial and two point boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations.
MATH 6646.title: Numerical Methods for Ordinary Differential Equations

MATH 6647.description: Approximation of the dynamical structure of a differential equation and preservation of dynamical structure under discretization.
MATH 6647.title: Numerical Methods for Dynamical Systems

MATH 6701.description: Review of linear algebra and ordinary differential equations, brief introduction to functions of a complex variable.
MATH 6701.offered: fa21, su21, fa20, su20, fa19, su19, fa18, su18, fa17, su17, fa16, su16
MATH 6701.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences I

MATH 6702.description: Review of vector calculus and and its application to partial differential equations.
MATH 6702.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6702.prereqs: MATH 6701, or MATH 2403 and one of MATH 2406, MATH 4305
MATH 6702.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences II

MATH 6705.description: Mathematical methods for solving problems in the life sciences. Models-based course on basic facts from the theory of ordinary differential equations and numerical methods of their solution. Introduction to the control theory, diffusion theory, maximization, minimization and curve fitting.
MATH 6705.prereqs: RESTRICTED to biology, bioinformatics, biomedical engineering, bioengineering, and chemistry students. Graduate students in other majors cannot take this course. Math majors may not use this course toward any degree in the School of Mathematics.
MATH 6705.title: Modeling and Dynamics

MATH 6759.description: Mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from probability and mathematics are introduced as needed. Crosslisted with ISYE 6759.
MATH 6759.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6759.prereqs: MATH 3215 and some knowledge of computer programming
MATH 6759.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance I

MATH 6761.description: Discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes and renewal processes. Transient and limiting behavior. Average cost and utility measures of systems. Algorithm for computing performance measures. Modeling of inventories, and flows in manufacturing and computer networks. (Also listed as ISyE 6761)
MATH 6761.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6761.title: Stochastic Processes I

MATH 6762.description: Continuous time Markov chains. Uniformization, transient and limiting behavior. Brownian motion and martingales. Optional sampling and convergence. Modeling of inventories, finance, flows in manufacturing and computer networks. (Also listed as ISyE 6762)
MATH 6762.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6762.title: Stochastic Processes II

MATH 6767.description: Introduction to large scale-system design to support computational finance for options, stocks, or other instruments.
MATH 6767.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6767.title: Design and Implementation of Systems to Support Computational Finance

MATH 6769.description: Description, institutional features, and mathematical modeling of fixed income securities. Use of both deterministic and stochastic models. Crosslisted with ISYE 6769.
MATH 6769.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6769.title: Fixed Income Securities

MATH 6781.description: Reliability systems and related distributions, failure rate functions and nonparametric classes, accelerated life testing, dependent failure analysis, statistical inference of reliability data. (Also listed as ISyE 6781)
MATH 6781.title: Reliability Theory

MATH 6783.description: Fundamentals of statistical inference are presented and developed for models used in the modern analysis of financial data. Techniques are motivated by examples and developed in the context of applications. Crosslisted with ISYE 6783.
MATH 6783.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 6783.prereqs: MATH 3215 (or equivalent), some knowledge of programming, and MS QCF standing or some previous exposure to the topics of stocks, bonds and options
MATH 6783.title: Statistical Techniques of Financial Data Analysis

MATH 6785.description: Case studies, visiting lecturers from financial institutions, student group projects of an advanced nature, and student reports, all centered around quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE and MGT 6785.
MATH 6785.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 6785.prereqs: MS QCF major or consent of the instructor
MATH 6785.title: The Practice of Quantitative and Computational Finance

MATH 7012.description: Fundamental methods of enumeration and asymptotic analysis, including the use of inclusion/exclusion, generating functions, and recurrence relations. Applications to strings over a finite alphabet and graphs.
MATH 7012.title: Enumerative Combinatorics

MATH 7014.description: Selection of topics vary with each offering.
MATH 7014.title: Advanced Graph Theory

MATH 7016.description: Fundamental combinatorial structures including hypergraphs, transversal sets, colorings, Sperner families, intersecting families, packings and coverings, perfect graphs, and Ramsey theory. Algebraic and topological methods, applications.
MATH 7016.prereqs: MATH 4022 or consent of the School
MATH 7016.title: Combinatorics

MATH 7018.description: Applications of probabilistic techniques in discrete mathematics, including classical ideas using expectation and variance as well as modern tools, such as martingale and correlation inequalities.
MATH 7018.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 7018.prereqs: MATH 4022 and MATH 6221 or consent of School
MATH 7018.title: Probabilistic Methods in Combinatorics

MATH 7244.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. (1st of two courses in sequence)
MATH 7244.offered: fa21, fa20, fa19, fa18, fa17, fa16
MATH 7244.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus I

MATH 7245.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. (2nd of two courses in sequence)
MATH 7245.offered: sp21, sp20, sp19, sp18, sp17, sp16
MATH 7245.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus II

MATH 7251.description: The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to the methods of high-dimensional probability.
MATH 7251.title: High-dimensional probability

MATH 7252.description:
The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to concepts and methods of high-dimensional statistics
having numerous applications in machine learning, data science and signal processing.
MATH 7252.title: High-Dimensional Statistics

MATH 7334.description: Theory of linear operators on Hilbert space; spectral theory of bounded and unbounded operators; applications
MATH 7334.title: Introduction to Operator Theory

MATH 7337.description: Fourier analysis in Euclidean space. Basic topics including L^1 and L^2 theory; advanced topics such as distribution theory, uncertainty, Littlewood-Paley theory
MATH 7337.title: Harmonic Analysis

MATH 7338.description: Topics include the Hahn-Banach theorems, the Baire Category theorem and its consequences, duality in Banach spaces, locally convex spaces, additional topics.
MATH 7338.title: Functional Analysis

MATH 7510.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, matching, network reliability, minimum cuts, covering, coloring, planarity, shortest paths, and connectivity. Crosslisted with CS 7510 and ISYE 7510.
MATH 7510.title: Graph Algorithms

MATH 7581.description: Minimization of functionals, Euler Lagrange equations, sufficient conditions for a minimum, geodesic, isoperimetric and time of transit problems, variational principles of mechanics, applications to control theory.
MATH 7581.title: Calculus of Variations

MATH 7586.description: Review of linear algebra, multilinear algebra, algebra of tensors, co- and cotravariant tensors, tensors in Riemann spaces, geometrical interpretation of skew tensors.
MATH 7586.prereqs: MATH 2403 and either MATH 2406 or MATH 4305
MATH 7586.title: Tensor Analysis

MATH 8801.description:
Seminar series in which different groups within the College of Sciences will give talks about how their research
relates to data sciences and machine learning.
MATH 8801.title: Seminar in Data Sciences

MATH 8801-BUR.description: Special topics course on The Academic and Industry Job Search in Mathematics offered in Fall 2018 by Morag Burke.
MATH 8801-BUR.prereqs: This course is for international PhD students in Math who are nearing the completion of their degree, and are preparing to go on the job market.
MATH 8801-BUR.title: The Academic and Industry Job Search in Mathematics

MATH 8803 HOU.description: Special Topics course offered in Spring 2017 by Christian Houdre.
MATH 8803 HOU.prereqs: Strong knowledge of Probability Theory at the level of MATH 7244
MATH 8803 HOU.title: Asymptotics in Sequence Comparison

MATH 8803 POP.description: Special topics on Introduction to Random Matrices offered in Spring 2016 by Ionel Popescu.
MATH 8803 POP.title: Introduction to Random Matrices

MATH 8803 TAO.description: Special topics on Applied Stochastic Dynamics offered in Spring 2016 by Molei Tao.
MATH 8803 TAO.title: Applied Stochastic Dynamics

MATH 8803-BAK.description: Special topics course on Topics in Matroid Theory, offered in Fall 2020 by Matt Baker.
MATH 8803-BAK.prereqs: MATH 6121 . Some background in graph theory, at the level of MATH 6014, would also be helpful.
MATH 8803-BAK.title: Topics in Matroid Theory

MATH 8803-BEA.description: Special topics course on Algebraic Topology, offered in Fall 2020 by Jonathan Beardsley.
MATH 8803-BEA.title: Topics in Algebraic Topology

MATH 8803-BER.description: Topics class offered in FALL 2021 by Anton Bernshteyn.
MATH 8803-BER.prereqs: Knowledge of the fundamentals of graph theory will be assumed, as well as some basic familiarity with measure theory and point-set topology (although the necessary background from these areas will be reviewed in the course). No prior knowledge of descriptive set theory is required.
MATH 8803-BER.title: Descriptive Combinatorics

MATH 8803-BLO.description: Special topics course on Topological Quantum Computing/Quantum Representations, offered in Spring 2021 by Wade Bloomquist.
MATH 8803-BLO.prereqs: An effort will be made to make this course accessible to as broad of an audience as possible. The following topics could be considered a rough list of prerequisite concepts:Topology of surfaces (for example isotopy of curves); Group theory; Linear algebra
MATH 8803-BLO.title: Introduction to Topological Quantum Computing/Quantum Representations

MATH 8803-BUR.description: Special topics course on The Academic and Industry Job Search offered in Fall 2017 by Morag Burke.
MATH 8803-BUR.title: The Academic and Industry Job Search

MATH 8803-DAM.description: Special Topics course offered in Fall 2020 by Michael Damron.
MATH 8803-DAM.title: Percolation Models

MATH 8803-ETN.description: Topics class offered in FALL 2021 by John Etnyre.
MATH 8803-ETN.prereqs: MATH 6452, MATH 6441 (though students without these courses still might be able to take the course-- they should talk to Dr. Etnyre about it).
MATH 8803-ETN.title: The topology of 3-manifolds

MATH 8803-FAT.prereqs: Math 6337 (Real Analysis I) Math 6338 (Real Analysis II)  Math Ordinary Differential Equations I
MATH 8803-FAT.title: Weak KAM Theorem: Lagrangian Dynamics and viscosity solutions of PDEs

MATH 8803-GHO.prereqs: Interest in geometry or its potential applications, together with mathematical maturity at the level of a beginning math grad student. There will be no specific course requirements; however, some familiarity with differential geometry (e.g., Math 6455) or manifold theory (e.g., Math 6452) could be helpful. Advanced undergraduate students with some knowledge of classical differential geometry of curves and surfaces (e.g., Math 4441) may also take this class.
MATH 8803-GHO.title: Isometric Embeddings

MATH 8803-HEI.description: Topics class offered in Spring 2020 by Christine Heitsch.
MATH 8803-HEI.prereqs: This class is aimed at Graduate students in bioinformatics, biomedical engineering, bioengineering, and quantitative biosciences (except those in SoM).
MATH 8803-HEI.title: Fundamentals of Discrete Mathematical Biology

MATH 8803-HOM.description: Special topics course on Introduction to Heegaard Floer homology offered in Fall 2017 by Jennifer Hom.
MATH 8803-HOM.title: Introduction to Heegaard Floer homology

MATH 8803-KOL.prereqs: An advanced probability course (ideally, at the level 6241)
MATH 8803-KOL.title: Topics in High-Dimensional Statistics

MATH 8803-LAC.description: Special topics course on Mathematical Introduction to Compressive Sensing, by Michael Lacey, offered Fall 2016.
MATH 8803-LAC.prereqs: MATH 4305 and familiarity with Gaussian random variables and stochastic processes
MATH 8803-LAC.title: Mathematical Introduction to Compressive Sensing

MATH 8803-LAM.description: Special Topics course offered in Spring 2018 by Peter Lambert-Cole on "4-Manifolds".
MATH 8803-LAM.title: 4-manifolds

MATH 8803-LIN.description: Special topics course offered in Fall 2018 by Zhiwu Lin on "Dynamics of Hamiltonian PDEs."
MATH 8803-LIN.title: Dynamics of Hamiltonian PDEs

MATH 8803-LIV.description: Special topics course on "High-dimensional geometry and probability" offered in Spring 2018 by Galyna Livshyts.
MATH 8803-LIV.prereqs: No prerequisites aside from Calculus I-III and an introduction to undergraduate Probability Theory
MATH 8803-LIV.title: High-dimensional geometry and probability

MATH 8803-LUB.description: Special topics course on Potential Theory offered by Doron Lubinsky in Fall 2016
MATH 8803-LUB.title: Potential Theory

MATH 8803-MAR.description: Special topics course on Mapping Class Groups, offered in Fall 2020 by Dan Margalit.
MATH 8803-MAR.title: Mapping Class Groups

MATH 8803-MAT.description: Special topics course offered in Spring 2018 by Henry Matzinger on "Big matrices and real life machine learning applied problems"
MATH 8803-MAT.title: Big matrices and real life machine learning applied  problems

MATH 8803-MCC.description: Special topics course on Mathematical Capillarity, offered in Spring 2021 by John McCuan.
MATH 8803-MCC.prereqs: No formal prerequisites are required beyond calculus and ODE’s
MATH 8803-MCC.title: Mathematical Capillarity

MATH 8803-PHD.description:
Pass/Fail only. A course for graduate students in Mathematics to help prepare for the written comprehensive exams in Algebra and Analysis. Offered Summer 2017.
In 2017, the course was split into two sections: MATH 8802 ALG and MATH 8802 ANA.
MATH 8803-PHD.prereqs: Knowledge of Abstract Algebra and/or Real Analysis at the level of our graduate coursework. Restricted to Graduate students in Mathematics.
MATH 8803-PHD.title: Mathematics Written Comps Preparatory Class

MATH 8803-RAE.description:
Special topics course offered in Summer 2018 by Christopher Heil and Shahaf Nitzan on "Real Analysis for Engineers".
This course can be taken in place of MATH 6337, Real Analysis, to satisfy the prerequisite for MATH 6241, Probability I.
This course cannot be used for credit at the same time as MATH 6337.
MATH 8803-RAE.title: Real Analysis for Engineers

MATH 8803-ROL.description: Special Topics course offered in Spring 2018 by Larry Rolen on "Modular Forms: Theory and Applications"
MATH 8803-ROL.title: Modular Forms: Theory and Applications

MATH 8803-SIN.description: Special topics course on Algebraic Curves, offered in Fall 2016 by Rainer Sinn.
MATH 8803-SIN.title: Algebraic Curves

MATH 8803-STR.prereqs: Differential topology (Math 6452) or permission of the instructor. Familiarity with some basics (Riemannian metrics and geodesics) from Differential Geometry I (Math 6455) is also recommended.
MATH 8803-STR.title: Geometric structures on surfaces

MATH 8803-WAN.description: Topics class offered in FALL 2021 by Zhiyu Wang.
MATH 8803-WAN.prereqs: Linear algebra and some familiarity with graph theory
MATH 8803-WAN.title: Spectral Graph Theory

MATH 8803-WAR.description: Special topics  course on Random Discrete Structures, offered in Fall 2017 by Lutz Warnke.
MATH 8803-WAR.prereqs: Math 6221 (Advanced Classical Probability Theory) or Math 7018 (Probabilistic Methods in Combinatorics) or Math 6241 (Probability I).
MATH 8803-WAR.title: Random Discrete Structures

MATH 8873.description:
This is a 2 week intense course, with lectures in the morning and computational lab in the afternoon.
Students will be asked to have a laptop with Matlab on it.

The course will meet in the mornings for lecture, break for  lunch, and reconvene for the lab in the afternoons.
MATH 8873.title: Computations in Dynamics
